content: This report focuses on USAID's global health programs for child survival and maternal health from FY2001 to FY2008. It discusses how advancements in addressing malaria can improve maternal and child survival. UNICEF's report in 2008 celebrated the decline in annual deaths among children under five. In 2008, UNICEF Executive Director Ann Veneman noted a 60% decrease in annual deaths of children under five since 1960. Despite this progress, around 26,000 children still die daily, with most deaths occurring in developing countries. About 4 million newborns die annually, with 37% of childhood deaths happening in the first 28 days. Child deaths are prevalent in developing countries, with 37% occurring in the neonatal period, resulting in about 4 million annual newborn deaths. The main causes are neonatal infections and diseases like pneumonia, diarrhea, malaria, measles, and HIV/AIDS. Undernutrition contributes to half of these deaths, highlighting the importance of maternal and child health monitoring. Maternal and child health are crucial to monitor as indicators of overall health conditions. The Millennium Development Goals aim to reduce child and maternal mortality rates, with progress in other goals impacting the ability to reach these targets. Countries with undernourished populations and limited access to clean water tend to have higher mortality rates. Countries with significant undernourished populations and limited access to clean water tend to have higher maternal and child mortality rates. Undernourished individuals are more likely to be impoverished and susceptible to infectious diseases. UNICEF reports that 62 countries show no progress in child survival goals, with a majority in Africa. Maternal health is closely linked to child survival, with over 500,000 women dying annually from pregnancy-related causes. Maternal health is closely linked to child survival, with over 500,000 women dying annually from pregnancy-related causes in developing countries. Access to adequate diets, safe water, sanitation facilities, basic literacy, and health services during pregnancy and childbirth could prevent most of these deaths. Maternal mortality in developing countries is linked to undernutrition and obstetric complications, with 20% of deaths due to undernutrition and 75% due to complications like hemorrhage, sepsis, and eclampsia. Young mothers under 20 are at higher risk, facing complications such as toxemia, anemia, and premature delivery. Adolescent girls, especially those under 20, face higher risks during pregnancy and delivery, including complications like toxemia, anemia, premature delivery, prolonged labor, and cervical trauma. They are also at a higher risk of delivering low birth weight babies, leading to higher morbidity and mortality rates. The United Nations estimates that adolescents give birth to 15 million infants each year, with girls aged 15-19 being twice as likely to die from childbirth compared to women in their twenties. Girls younger than 15 are five times as likely to die. The maternal mortality rate is higher for adolescent girls, with those aged 15-19 facing a rate of 178 per 100,000 live births. Hemorrhage is a significant cause of maternal deaths in Africa and Asia, accounting for about 34% and 31% respectively. Regions with fewer skilled health attendants at birth have higher mortality rates. Regions with low proportions of skilled health attendants at birth have higher maternal mortality rates. In sub-Saharan Africa, 43% of women give birth with skilled attendants, 65% in south Asia, and 99% in industrialized nations. In sub-Saharan Africa, one in every 22 women is at risk of dying from pregnancy-related causes, compared to one in every 59 Asian women and one in every 8,000 women in industrialized nations. Child and maternal survival rates are higher in areas with sufficient health workers, clean water, controlled mosquito populations, and access to nutritious food. Sub-Saharan Africa faces the greatest proportional shortage of health care workers globally, with 36 out of 57 countries with critical shortages located in Africa. No industrialized nations are among the countries with critical shortages. The WHO estimates that 57 countries, including 36 in Africa, have critical shortages of health care workers. An additional 4.3 million health workers are needed globally, with African countries needing to increase their health workers by 140% to meet the minimum threshold. Exclusively breastfed infants have fewer childhood diseases and are less likely to die from acute respiratory infections. One USAID-supported study found that exclusively breastfed infants have significantly lower rates of childhood diseases and are less likely to die from respiratory infections and diarrheal diseases. Fixed-dosed treatments combining multiple drugs in a single pill are most effective but more expensive for children. WHO states that measles immunization is a cost-effective intervention for preventing childhood deaths. The measles vaccine is a cost-effective public health intervention that can reduce childhood deaths. It costs less than $1 per dose and has been available for over 40 years. In countries where rubella and mumps are significant public health concerns, the measles vaccine is often combined with them. The measles vaccine is often combined with rubella and/or mumps vaccines in countries where they are significant public health concerns. Their maternal health programs aim to improve pregnancy outcomes in low-resource settings through various interventions. USAID's maternal health programs focus on ensuring healthy pregnancy outcomes in low-resource environments through interventions like nutritional supplementation, treatment for parasitic worms, immunizations, prevention of mother-to-child HIV transmission, malaria treatment, and syphilis detection. They advocate for skilled birth attendants at all births and emergency obstetric care plans for home deliveries. Birth attendants are trained to prevent infant deaths. USAID trains birth attendants to prevent infant deaths by facilitating infant breathing, resuscitating, and providing care for birth asphyxia. They also promote hygienic cord and eye care, immediate breastfeeding, and develop contingency plans for accessing emergency obstetric care for mothers who deliver at home. Community-based interventions include teaching families to recognize birth complications, arranging transportation to a hospital, identifying blood donors, and creating savings plans for healthcare costs. USAID addresses key causes of maternal mortality by training birth attendants to prevent postpartum hemorrhage deaths through low-cost interventions. They urge communities to ensure mothers give birth in the presence of a trained health care practitioner who can administer life-saving techniques. USAID-supported programs train birth attendants to actively manage postpartum hemorrhage by using drugs and life-saving techniques. This intervention can prevent 60% of hemorrhages. Infections cause nearly 10% of maternal deaths, with unhygienic delivery practices identified as a key factor. USAID-supported efforts aim to prevent sepsis in mothers and babies by addressing unhygienic delivery practices. This includes distributing delivery kits, ensuring trained delivery attendants are present at each birth, and training birth attendants to identify signs of infection and provide necessary treatment. USAID trains birth attendants to identify signs of infection and use antibiotics to prevent sepsis in mothers and babies. They also train healthcare providers to recognize and treat hypertensive disorders, including pre-eclampsia and eclampsia. Additionally, USAID provides support for mothers experiencing prolonged or obstructed labor. Prolonged or obstructed labor can lead to serious complications for both the mother and baby, including obstetric fistula. This condition is more common in women in low-resource settings, especially those who were stunted due to undernourishment and lack access to obstetric care. In low-resource settings, girls and women with underdeveloped pelvic regions due to undernourishment are at higher risk of developing obstetric fistula. Delaying pregnancy until the pelvic region is fully developed, ensuring access to emergency obstetric care, and performing caesarean surgery when necessary can prevent obstetric fistula. These programs aim to increase access to emergency obstetrical care, delay child marriage, train health practitioners to identify labor complications, and reduce stigma around obstetric fistula.
